description: From Middle English *schagge, from Old English sċeacga (“hair, wool”), from Proto-Germanic *skaggô, *skaggiją (“projection, bristly hair, stem”), *skag- (“to emerge, stick out, protrude”), possibly from Proto-Indo-European *(s)kek- (“to jump, move, hurry”).
Akin to Old Norse skegg (“beard”) (compare Danish skæg, Norwegian skjegg, Swedish skägg). Related to shake and shock via the root.

adjectives.description: shag (comparative more shag, superlative most shag)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Hairy; shaggy.
Matted material; rough massed hair, fibres etc.
Coarse shredded tobacco.
A type of rough carpet pile.
(UK, archaic) Bacon or fat, especially if with some remaining hair or bristles.
(UK, archaic) A roughly-cut or torn-off piece of bread or cheese.
(often attributive) A deliberately messy, shaggy hairstyle.
examples: There was that hair salon on Yonge Street called House of Lords. On a Saturday – nowadays you can't even imagine it – but imagine a hair salon having a lineup outside of people wanting to get a shag haircut.

verbs.description: shag (third-person singular simple present shags, present participle shagging, simple past and past participle shagged)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make hairy or shaggy; to roughen.
(intransitive, obsolete) To hang in shaggy clusters.

description: Perhaps a derivative of Etymology 1, above, with reference to the bird's shaggy crest.

entries.meaning: Any of several species of sea birds in the family Phalacrocoracidae (cormorant family), especially the common shag or European shag, Phalacrocorax aristotelis, found on European and African coasts.
examples: He ran back and picked up a dead bird that had fallen. It was not a duck but a shag.

description: From Middle English schaggen, a variant of Middle English schoggen (“to shake; shake off; tremble”), of uncertain origin. Perhaps a byform of Middle English schokken (“to shake; move rapidly”), related to Middle Low German schokken (“to shake; tremble”). Alternatively, perhaps ultimately from Proto-Germanic *skakkōną (“to shake”), specifically continuing a post-Proto-Germanic variant *skagg-, where the non-singular stem *skag- caused the analogical replacement of the stem-final voiceless geminate consonants with voiced geminates, which was then leveled throughout the paradigm.

entries.meaning: (dance, sometimes capitalized) A swing dance.
(slang, vulgar) An act of sexual intercourse.
(slang, vulgar) A casual sexual partner.

verbs.description: shag (third-person singular simple present shags, present participle shagging, simple past and past participle shagged)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To shake, wiggle around.
examples: Synonyms: jiggle, rock, tremble; see also Thesaurus:shake

entries.meaning: (UK, Ireland, transitive, vulgar slang) To have sexual intercourse with.
(UK, Ireland, intransitive, vulgar slang) To have sexual intercourse.
(India, transitive, vulgar slang) To masturbate.
To chase after; especially, to chase after and return (a ball) hit usually out of play.
(dance, uncommon) To perform the dance called the shag.

description: Blend of shower (“bridal shower”) +‎ stag (“bachelor party”).

entries.meaning: (Northwestern Ontario) A fundraising dance in honour of a couple engaged to be married.
(West Country) Friend; mate; buddy.
